   Mrs. [**Known lastname 10054**] is a 70 year old female with history of hypertension,
   glaucoma, and asthma who came with subjective fevers, sore throat, and
   now in respiratory failure.
   .
   #) ARDS/hypercarbic respiratory failure: Pt is now s/p intubation and
   bronchoscopy. Differential for patient's respiratory distress at this
   time remains broad, includes viral syndrome/ARDS, AIP, interstitial
   pneumonitis. She describes a prodrome lasting a few weeks, however
   relatively acute onset of shortness of breath today on day of
   presentation. Her chest x-ray is not completely consistent with a
   picture of just CHF, and she did not respond to lasix as expected if
   this was the whole story.  Her fevers are more suggestive of an
   infectious process; given her chest x-ray an atypical process such as
   legionella or mycoplasma would be higher on the differential. Viral
   process (such as varicella, CMV) would also be possibilties. She has no
   known risk factors for PCP.  [**Name10 (NameIs) **] considerations would be
   rheumatologic processes (vasculitis, pulmonary-renal syndromes, however
   renal function is WNL), institial lung diseases such as UIP/AIP/DIP,
   hypersensitivity pneumonitis, bronchoalveolar carcinoma. No hemoptysis
   to suggest DAH, and suctions from ETT and bronchoscopy showed no rustic
   blood color or alveolar bleeding.  Patient meets the criteria for ARDS
   as it is acute, no evidence of CHF, PaO2/FiO2 <200 and pt has bilateral
   infiltrates on CXR. In terms of the precipitate of ARDS, could be
   aspiration pneumonitis, viral or atypical pneumonia, or inhalation in
   the environment. No evidence of pancreatitis, sepsis, no h/o
   transfusion, trauma, drown, or burn. No h/o drug overdose either.
   - continue on PC (PEEP of 10 and driving pressure of 12), weaned FiO2
   to 50%, ABG shows compensated respiratory acidosis; continue high RR of
   30
   - continue methadone 20mg Q4h, and continue to wean off fentanyl and
   midazolam
   - completed 3 day course of high-dose steroids salumederol (1g daily x
   3days) for possible rheumatologic/vasculitis etiology
   - started Prednisone taper yesterday
   - d/c azithro today as a 5d course is finished
   - changed [**Last Name (un) 614**] to 500 mg q12h (day 1: [**8-13**]) now that renal function
   improved
   - continue tamiflu; if viral culture negative for 72 hours, plan to
   discontinue
   - f/u extensive pendng cultures, scleroderma studies
   - no antifungal per ID
   - opted against lung bx for now as risk too high with thorocotomy
   .
   #) Sepsis: Patient meets the criteria for sepsis. In terms of the
   sources of infection, pulmonary infection is certainly high on the
   differential. Concening as white count elevated GI sources are also
   possible but pt had no GI complaint on admission. Pt has no skin
   breakdown to explain this sepsis.
   - pt is afebrile, Eleveated WBC today to 12, off pressors since [**8-16**]
   - continue [**Last Name (un) 614**] and tamiflu as per ID
   - continue to follow all cultures, c. diff neg x2; #3 pending
   - lactate normal
   - dental rec tooth extractionas outpt, pt unable to have panorex
   currently
   - maintain MAP>65, CVP>[**9-3**], UOP>30cc/hr and ScvO2 > 70%
   .
   #) hypernatremia: Free water deficit: 3.875 L provide 250cc free water
   bolus q6h.  Obtain urine lytes today.
   #) Acute renal failure: Improving Cr continues to trend down 1.4 today
   (baseline 1.0).  FeNa 0.36, Urine Na 18, consistent with pre-renal
   etiology. Per renal, pt has muddy brown casts, most likely ATN in the
   setting of hypotension. In the setting of ARDS with bilateral
   infiltrate, question patient has pulmonary
renal syndrome/vasculitis.
   Anemia is supportive of this possible diagnosis. [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 10093**] is
   also supportive, however ANCA neg.
   - Cr trending down, continue to monitor
   - maintain renal perfusion by MAP>65, CVP>[**9-3**], UOP>30cc/hr

   - f/u renal recs (no dialysis since Cr is improving)

   - RUQ US only showed gallbladder sludge without evidence of
   cholecystitis
   - trend LFTs daily
   .
   #) Hyperphosphatemia: Most likely [**12-25**] ARF.  Improved.

   - continue to trend

The patient is a 70-year-old female with a history of hypertension, glaucoma, and asthma who presented with subjective fevers, sore throat, and is now in respiratory failure. The patient underwent intubation and bronchoscopy. The differential diagnosis for the patient's respiratory distress includes viral syndrome/ARDS, acute interstitial pneumonia, and congestive heart failure (CHF). However, the chest X-ray is not completely consistent with CHF, and the patient did not respond to lasix as expected if this was the whole story.

The patient's fevers are more suggestive of an infectious process; given her chest X-ray, an atypical process such as Legionella or Mycoplasma would be higher on the differential. Viral processes (such as varicella or cytomegalovirus) are also possibilities. The patient has no known risk factors for Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP). Other considerations include rheumatologic processes (vasculitis, pulmonary-renal syndromes), interstitial lung diseases (UIP/AIP/DIP), hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and bronchoalveolar carcinoma. No evidence of hemoptysis to suggest diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH), and suctions from the endotracheal tube and bronchoscopy showed no rust-colored blood or alveolar bleeding.

Summary:
The patient's medical history includes hypertension, glaucoma, and asthma. She presented with subjective fevers, sore throat, and respiratory failure. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a diagnosis of ARDS/hypercarbic respiratory failure. The differential for her respiratory distress includes viral syndrome/ARDS, acute interstitial pneumonitis (AIP), and other atypical pneumonia. The chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates, which are more suggestive of an infectious process such as Legionella or Mycoplasma. Viral processes like varicella or CMV are also possible.

The patient meets the criteria for ARDS, which is acute, with no evidence of congestive heart failure (CHF), and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of less than 200. She has bilateral infiltrates on the chest X-ray. Given her unresponsiveness to steroids, AIP is a high possibility. The precipitate of ARDS could be aspiration pneumonitis, viral or atypical pneumonia, or inhalation injury. There is no evidence of pancreatitis, sepsis, no history of transfusion, trauma, drowning, or burn.

The patient's current medications include methadone 20mg IV q4h, fentanyl decreased from 150 to 125 mcg/hr, midazolam decreased from 5 to 4 mg/hr, pantoprazole (Protonix), heparin sodium (prophylaxis), and other ICU medications. The patient has been on a 3-day course of high-dose steroids for possible rheumatologic/vasculitis etiology and has been started on prednisone taper.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 37.2 C (98.9 F)
- Heart rate: 67 bpm
- Blood pressure: 149/68 mmHg
- Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation: 94%
- Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's physical examination reveals a right pupil that constricts to light, a left pupil with a cataract and no response to light, scattered rhonchi on lung auscultation, regular heart rhythm with normal S1 and S2 sounds, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops, soft non-tender abdomen with present bowel sounds, Foley catheter in place, and mild bilateral edema.

Laboratory results show:
- White blood cell count: 12.0 K/uL
- Hemoglobin: 10.7 g/dL
- Sodium: 154 mEq/L
- Potassium: 3.9 mEq/L
- Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL
- Blood urea nitrogen: 28 mEq/L
- Glucose: 193 mg/dL
- Total bilirubin: 2

The patient is a 70-year-old female who was admitted with subjective fevers, sore throat, and respiratory failure. She has been diagnosed with Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) of unclear etiology, which is nonresponsive to steroids. The patient is currently intubated on pressure-controlled ventilation/pressure support ventilation (PCV+/PSV) and is being weaned off sedation slowly. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.9°C, heart rate of 66 beats per minute, blood pressure of 158/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 29 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%. The patient's recent laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelets, blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, lactate dehydrogenase, and liver enzymes. The urinalysis indicates renal impairment. 

The patient's medical history includes allergies to simvastatin, niacin, sulfonamides, penicillins, and enalapril maleate. The patient has had multiple antibiotic courses including azithromycin and meropenem. 

The potential medical complications that can arise include ARDS, hypercarbic respiratory failure, sepsis, acute renal failure, hypernatremia, elevated liver function tests, anemia, and decreased bowel movements. The patient is currently receiving treatment for these conditions, including mechanical ventilation, fluid resuscitation, antibiotics, renal support, and

1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient has been diagnosed with ARDS, which is characterized by severe inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs. This can lead to difficulty breathing and inadequate oxygenation.

2. Hypernatremia (High Sodium): The patient's serum sodium level is elevated, indicating hypernatremia. This can result in dehydration and neurological symptoms if not corrected promptly.

3. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are consistently high, indicating hyperglycemia. This can increase the risk of infections and complications related to poor wound healing.

4. Hyperphosphatemia (High Phosphate): The patient's phosphate levels are elevated, which may indicate impaired renal function. Elevated phosphate levels can contribute to various complications, including bone demineralization and cardiac dysfunction.

5. Renal Failure, Acute (ARF): The patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest acute renal failure. ARF can lead to fluid and electrolyte imbalances, increased risk of infection, and other systemic complications.

6. Fever, Unknown Origin (FUO): The patient has an unexplained fever, which can be indicative of an underlying infection or inflammatory process. It is important to investigate and treat the underlying cause to prevent further complications.

7. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's symptoms and imaging findings suggest the

- Tamiflu was stopped as the viral culture had been negative for 72 hours.
- Extensive pending cultures, scleroderma studies, and no antifungal per ID are planned.
- A lung biopsy was opted against due to the high risk of thoracotomy.

   .

s wishes were to not have a trach.
   -          d/c meds
   -          start morphine
   -          contact social work
   #) ARDS/hypercarbic respiratory failure Intubated on PCV/PSV.
   Differential for patient's respiratory distress at this time remains
   broad, includes viral syndrome/ARDS, AIP, interstitial pneumonitis. Her
   fevers are more suggestive of an infectious process;. Viral process
   (such as varicella, CMV) would also be possibilties. Other
   considerations would be rheumatologic processes (vasculitis,
   pulmonary-renal syndromes, however renal function is WNL), institial
   lung diseases such as UIP/AIP/DIP, hypersensitivity pneumonitis,
   bronchoalveolar carcinoma. Patient meets the criteria for ARDS as it is
   acute, no evidence of CHF, PaO2/FiO2 <200 and pt has bilateral
   infiltrates on CXR.
   - continue on PC; FiO2 to 50%, ABG; continue to taper vent settings as
   tolerated.
   - continue methadone 20mg Q4h, Valium 5 mg IV q 6 hours and and attempt
   to wean off fentanyl and midazolam as tolerated
   - completed 3 day course of high-dose steroids salumederol (1g daily x
   3days) for possible rheumatologic/vasculitis etiology
   - Continue Prednisone taper (started [**8-18**])
   - d/c azithro [**8-19**] as a 5d course is finished
   - changed [**Last Name (un) 614**] to 500 mg q12h (day 1: [**8-13**]) now that renal function
   improved stop [**8-23**]^st .
   - Stop tamiflu as  viral culture had been negative for 72 hours
   - f/u extensive pending cultures, scleroderma studies
   - no antifungal per ID
   - opted against lung bx for now as risk too high with thorocotomy
   .
   #) Sepsis: Patient meets the criteria for sepsis. In terms of the
   sources of infection, pulmonary infection is certainly high on the
   differential.
   - pt with low grade temps to 100,  WBC continuing to climb today to
   16.5, off pressors since [**8-16**]
   - continue [**Last Name (un) 614**] as per ID and stop [**8-23**].
   - continue to follow all cultures, c. diff neg x2
   - lactate normal
   - dental rec tooth extractionas outpt, pt unable to have panorex
   currently
   - maintain MAP>65, CVP>[**9-3**], UOP>30cc/hr and ScvO2 > 70%
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Free water deficit:  4.1 Liters after 250 cc free
   water boluses q 3 hours and 100 cc/hr of D5W for 1000 mL
   -   500 cc free water bolus q3h per renal
   -   100 cc/hr of D5W for 24 hours per renal
   -  Change all medications to D5W medium as can be accomplished; spoke
   with Rx and will make adjustments as needed
   #) Acute renal failure: Improved Cr continues to trend down 0.9 today
   (baseline 1.0).  FeNa 0.36, Urine Na 18, consistent with pre-renal
   etiology and with  muddy brown casts, ATN in the setting of
   hypotension.
   - Cr at baseline and BUN trending down, continue to monitor
   - maintain renal perfusion by MAP>65, CVP>[**9-3**], UOP>30cc/hr
   - anti-GBM negative
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: slowly increasing; in the setting of acute illness,
   concerning for acalculous cholecystitis,
   - RUQ US only showed gallbladder sludge without evidence of
   cholecystitis
   - trend LFTs daily
   ..
   #) Anemia: Hct stable, s/p 2 units prbcs [**8-18**]. Iron studies are
   consistent with anemia of chronic disease or anemia of inflammation,
   B12 and folate normal.
   - Transfusion threshold <21 or evidence of active bleeding
   .
   # Mental Status: currently sedated.
   - wean down fentanyl and midazolam
   - per pharmacy, continue methadone 20mg Q4h
   - Continue diazepam 5 mg IV q 6 hours
   - can re-assess neuro status when pt is less sedated
   .
   # Decreased bowel movements: Concern for narcotic induced ileus;
   although standing lactulose has generated large bowel movements
   -          Change lactulose today PO to PRN
   -          Send off C.diff

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old female admitted with subjective fevers, sore throat, and respiratory failure. The patient has been diagnosed with Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) of unclear etiology, nonresponsive to steroids, and minimal change from the previous day. The patient's wishes are to avoid tracheostomy, so extubation is planned for today.

The patient's respiratory distress differential includes viral syndrome/ARDS, Acute Interstitial Pneumonitis (AIP), interstitial pneumonitis, and other possibilities such as rheumatologic processes (vasculitis, pulmonary-renal syndromes), hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and bronchoalveolar carcinoma. The patient meets the criteria for ARDS, which is acute, with no evidence of congestive heart failure (CHF), PaO2/FiO2 <200, and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray.

The patient also has sepsis, with low-grade temperatures to 100, WBC continuing to climb, and off pressors since August 16th. The source of infection is suspected to be pulmonary infection. The patient is being treated with [Last Name (un) 614] as per ID and will stop on August 23rd. Cultures and c. diff status will be followed.

Hypernatremia is present, with a free water deficit of 4.1 liters. The patient has received 250 cc

MAP >65, CVP >[9-3], UOP >30cc/hr, and ScvO2 >70% were maintained.

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old male who remains on mechanical ventilation in the ICU due to respiratory failure secondary to ARDS, pneumonia, and hypernatremia. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.2°C, heart rate of 73 bpm, blood pressure of 164/76 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 91%. The patient's medical history is significant for obesity, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient's allergies include sulfonamides, penicillins, and niacin.

The patient's laboratory values show elevated sodium levels (143 mEq/L), glucose levels (194 mg/dL), and phosphate levels (4.7 mg/dL). The patient's white blood cell count is slightly elevated at 16.5 K/uL, and platelet count is within normal range at 394 K/uL. Other lab results including creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, liver function tests, and electrolytes are within normal limits.

The patient's respiratory status has shown marginal improvement with the ability to tolerate lower levels of PEEP. However, the family has decided to shift priorities to comfort measures rather than pursuing aggressive treatment options such as tracheostomy and continued mechanical ventilation. Social work has been notified, and the plan is to extubate the patient after the family arrives.
